name: places/ChIJE_xuhXVZwokR6efVoP5x41g
formattedAddress: 15 E 13th St, New York, NY 10003, USA
adrFormatAddress: 15 E 13th St, New York, NY 10003, USA

editorialSummary.text: French-Japanese cakes, pastries & other sweets, plus charcuterie & mains, in a small, stylish cafe.

originalText.text:
I started visiting to Patisserie Fouet shortly after it opened at the end of August in 2018 as I began studying at Parsons and Iâ€™ve been a patron of Fouet for over 5 years now!

The croissants and the soba pudding are honestly my all-time favourite desserts in New York. The yuzu matcha lemonade is the epitome of a balanced, Not Too Sweet drink for the summer (or winter - I do both). Their tea selection is well curated and in general, their coffee + tea + juices menu can appeal to any taste. Their sparkling wine selection pairs perfectly with their desserts, so itâ€™s the perfect place to come to after dinner!

Iâ€™ve visited the bakery through tweaks and different staff and have always felt warmly welcomed even when I felt silly for coming 2-3 days in a row. Iâ€™ve seen the staff handle high pressure situations with grace and compassion, so trust that youâ€™ll be treated kindly!

I come here solo most of the time so visiting Patisserie Fouet always feels warm. The music is always lovely (jazz!), the lighting is not overstimulating, and the energy of the space is welcoming to all - whether youâ€™re a tired student looking to indulge yourself with a sweet treat, with your kids, or with your picky parents (my Indian parents with spectrums of sweet tolerance adored the space and their desserts!).

The pictures Iâ€™ve taken were taken during different occasions, a potential testament to just how much Iâ€™ve frequented this establishment ðŸ˜…!

5/5 - I canâ€™t recommend Patisserie Fouet enough âœ¨

originalText.text:
A cute Japanese-inspired patisserie near Union Square. The warm hanging lights, wooden furnishings and bar stools give a retro-tinged Showa Era vibe. We were overexcited to see the wide selection of cakes in their display shelves!

ï¼Š Soba Pudding
Favorite among all! It wasÂ filled with a silky smooth pudding and topped with a soba cookie giving a satisfying crunch. As our spoon reached the bottom, we could savour the caramel syrup, which created a slightly bitterness against the sweet eggy custard. To me it was more like a regular vanilla pudding as the soba flavor was very subtle, but overall an enjoyable treat.

ï¼Š Black Sesame Apricot Pudding
The black sesame mousse stood out itself as it was bursting with strong nuttiness, yet the combination of chocolate frost (top) and apricot jam (bottom) didnâ€™t compliment well with one another. It was a pity that the design of this dessert cup was a total failure even though each layer was decadent separately.  I had a feeling their Black Sesame Latte will taste really good though.

ï¼Š Strawberry Shortcake
The jar was loaded with airy whipped cream and sliced strawberries, finished with meringue at the bottom. Yet the sponge cake was too porous and rough. It was a delightful treat but this price point ($11) I expected something more delicate.

ï¼Š Chamomile Mango Mousse
Beautifully crafted mousse cake with a edible chrysanthemum and white chocolate crunches garnished on top. Wrapped inside the smooth cream, it featured sweet mango purÃ©e and sponge cake. It even had fake moss on the side. Sadly the bottom cookie was soggy.

ï¼Š Iced Matcha Latte, Royal Oolong Milk Tea
Upon our first sip, we could already tell the tea they used was top tier. The matcha was still too mild for my liking but the premium aroma won me over. No extra sugar was added to the drinks so it was a huge bonus.

originalText.text: An exquisite experience at Patisserie Fouet in Manhattan! The $32 tasting menu is an absolute steal, offering a culinary journey through delicate, flavorful pastries. The souffle, a true highlight, melts in your mouth with its light and airy perfection. A must-visit for anyone seeking top-quality, affordable French indulgence. Highly recommended!

text.text: An exquisite experience at Patisserie Fouet in Manhattan! The $32 tasting menu is an absolute steal, offering a culinary journey through delicate, flavorful pastries. The souffle, a true highlight, melts in your mouth with its light and airy perfection. A must-visit for anyone seeking top-quality, affordable French indulgence. Highly recommended!

originalText.text:
A cozy little Cafe setting offering unique flavors and visuals in little packaged concoctions. Patisserie Fouet has a reasonably long line a lot of times because their food is just that popular, and for good reason. They mix unique flavors from both traditionally eastern and western cuisines, combined with fine technique to churn out wonderful little sweets.
I highly recommend the soba jarred dessert. The crispy cracker on top is wonderfully toasted and the custard below is rich and not too sweet.
They also have a tasting menu, but be sure to check the time, because it starts and ends within an allotted period of the day. I will be back to try this, as I was too early last time.
The servers are hard at work serving up both the sit ins and the ones at the pastry case. Outdoor seating is very limited so you may have to wait a bit for a table if you want to dine in. However, the experience is worth it given you have the money to shell out for something a bit off the beaten path.

originalText.text: A nice cozy cafe with pretty desserts. The basil green apple mousse was very tasty, I was expecting it to be super sweet, but it wasnâ€™t, it was light and pleasant. Wish it had been a little bigger though. The black sesame latte was really good, again not too sweet which was nice.
